rComments: Very illegible hand writing, which takes away from his lectures as you are trying to figure out what he wrote instead of focusing on new concepts. He needs to use powerpoint. No clear grading criteria as two identical papers can receive different grades depending on his mood at the time of grading.  Absolutely terrible Professor. AVOID at all cost.

Took this class freshman year. The three writing assignments were the hardest part of the class, and a good TA is key if you're not understanding the material right away. Does quite a few examples in class. Goes off on tangents sometimes. Wants students to do well in the class and holds office hours quite often.

As all the previous posters the book has to many errors some of the homework problems are impossible because of this. Quiz every class on definitions from the text, lectures are like reading straight from the text. 1st day of class "Ive heard I'm a bad professor but I'm tenured so it doesn't matter."-B.C But his reviews will help for midtermfinal.

He truly wants everyone to pass the class. Never went to class since I learned everything from the textbook he wrote himself and by going to section. Midterms and final are extremely similar to the practice ones. I think his grading is fair and you will do well if you put in the work to study for the exams.

He is by far the worst math prof ever. He goes so fast, his book (which he wrote) is terrible, he cares more about definitions and theorems. He isn't a good teach for this class, unless you can keep up. Please don't take him. You won't enjoy class. You can stay home and look up videos on YouTube. There is no point in attending class.

Wrote his own textbook with a mistake on every page.  Incomprehensible lectures that are a word for word regurgitation of the text.  Rude to students who ask questions, quizzes every single class on definitions straight out of the book.  Difficult subject made nearly impossible by poor instruction.  I do not recommend Cooperstein for any class.

He overcomplicates the material and is very unapproachable.  I wouldn't recommend anyone to take this class with him unless they are willing to learn all the material on their own. He seems nice when he is lecturing but if you ask questions he isn't very helpful.

Bad lecturer, but enthusiastic. Requires attendance or nobody would come. Uses his own book which has lots of typos and is not a very clear presentation. Lots of points for busywork, and tests are not too hard so possible to do well in his class without really understanding the material. If you want to learn much, you will have to teach yourself.

teaches way more than any other math 100 offered, he brings in material from his upper div algebra class instead of just having us learn proofs only. pretty annoying seeing as the class is hard enough as it is. assigns a lot of busy work. his lectures are unclear, and he constantly makes typos that will make you waste hours on homework.

He wrote the book, asks for a writeup on each section after you read the book at home, then writes the book on the board during class, and reads out loud what he's written. And the book is not great. Good stuff: He is clear in writing proofs and fair in his grading. Know the review sheets -- the tests are almost the same.

Cooperstein was a very, very poor instructor and used the book he wrote that definitely had more than enough errors. Definitely missed a lot of important sections of linear algebra and talked through class, rather than taught. I recommend taking the class with any other professor, as I decided to. It definitely helped to go elsewhere.

Bruce is a great teacher. He challenges your mathematical thinking, encouraging you to push your boundaries and use superior reasoning. If you attend class, go to section, and really get involved and be proactive with the material, this class is an easy A.

Overall, he's not terrible, he just moves really fast and doesn't get that not everyone is a math major. My big problem is that he gave us a practice midterm to review with, but giving us the answers was too much work. I just don't like how unwilling he is to do his own job. If you put in the work his class is doable, but a little hard.

This guy is hard as hell because he goes very fast and into a lot of theory if u can't keep up you are dead.another thing you cannot read anything he writes at all and beraks at least 5 chalk sticks to bits in each lecture. He is really big on definitions so def memorize them. He uses the book he wrote. If u don't study you will definitely fail. However he will try his hardest to pass you if you do ok

Prof. Cooperstein is fantastic. He's explains the math, then tells you about it in layman's terms, then tells you why it matters, then does examples, then makes you laugh:p he accidentally posted our midterm then just changed the numbers when he rewrote it, the reviews are useful. GET HIM FOR 21!

He knows his stuff and is actually a pretty laid back guy who really wants students to succeed. His tests and grading are fair. Do the homework, go to class, do practice exam you'll be fine. Lots of chances for extra credit and lots of office hours. Made a tough subject accessible and will get you through the course if you put in the work.
Has more personality than most math teachers, making lectures somewhat bearable.  Very fair tests and good review problems.

Yes there is a ton of busy work in this class but if you do well on the midterms and final you will be fine. He really wants students to succeed and that is clear by the amount of work he puts in. Concepts were tough so go to section so the book can actually make sense. The tests were all really easy and very similar to the practice.

I disagree with the other reviewers who suggest that Cooperstein is a poor instructor because he focuses on definitions and not calculations. I found that his course in linear algebra has provided an excellent basis for more advanced topics; his exercises were well-designed but accessible, and for me, the course was very rewarding.

Don't be fooled by his attitude in class, Bruce is a really nice guy if you go to his office hours. His tests are fair enough but he is not so generous with the partial credit. Lots of quizes, lots of homework, lots or reading assignments and lots of opportunity for extra credit. He may not be the clearest guy but he seems to love what he does.

If you like a literature class that requires you to recite math definitions word for word according to the textbook he wrote, this is the class for u. If you want a math class where calculations matter, don't take this class. Lose a lot of points for having the write calculations but not having word for word theorem he wrote to explain

Coop was confusing in lecture, jumped around a lot, often did not answer questions directly. He was a difficult grader, gave no partial credit. He was VERY enthusiastic about linear algebra and willing to help students. Required to use his book, which was confusing as well. Overall, his teaching was confusing and not clear.

In the essence of fairness 10 weeks is not enough to cover everything in 100. Despite missing class Coop covered the text and still had time for review.Assigns HW and Reading Assessments regularly so allocate AT LEAST 4 hours/day for his class.His typos gave me fits while I was doing the HW so watch out.Gives hella extra credit so an A is doable.

Do not take Cooperstein for Math 100, i repeat do not take. His lectures are boring. He thinks he's so funny but he's not. I use to be a math major because all the other math teachers I had at ucsc was really good. They made me like math alot but after taking this course, i decided to change majors. He is the worst.

Attendance was mandatory while the class was pretty boring. He requires you to do write-ups on the reading, then lectures directly from the book on the exact same reading. Later in the course he makes you read additional material from his own book, but his book is confusing and just throws definitions at you. Easy class, but avoid if possible.

Gotta give it to Coop. He LOVES math, and is quite a good teacher.  He definitely poses very challenging ideas for a lower division teacher, but then he doesn't expect you to know these ideas on exams so it's fair.  I personally liked his Liberal New Yorker attitude and elucidation of important mathematical concepts.  GO COOP!

Much clearer then previous MATH 21 teacher.  I don't see how anyone who put work and effort into this class could fail it.  reading abstracts kinda suck but they don't really impact your grade that much so you can just turn in a blank sheet of paper with your name on it.  Go over practice exams he posts and you'll pass that class.

Hard. This class involves lots of vocabulary that you just have to memorize in order to succeed. Do lots of problems, go to section, and consider multiple linear algebra textbooks. He sounds like a bit of a jerk, but it's hard to tell since he's from Queens...

Terrible.  No partial credit for anything...seems in the end most work is done for nothing.  No explanation for a low grade.  Hard to follow, teaches word for word his own textbook.  Therefore, you have no other source of information except TA's who haven't had him.

It's only my first two days of class and I'm getting so confused. He doesn't even explain well. His book doesn't even help at all. I rather use other textbooks to learn from. But he says "they're too expensive, so i wrote my own." But i don't even understand his text. horrible. just horrible.

Coop is full of himself. His class is difficult and he's a jerk and his lectures can be impossible to follow and the tests may be the most difficult thing you've ever looked at, but you'll come out knowing the material. Also, there are tons of extra credit points to take care of you. Go to office hours.

Damn, this class was freakin hard, homeworks, abstracts, 2 quizzes a week, hard midterm. BUT, Cooperstein wants you to learn. And if you show him that you've learned at the end of the class, he'll pass you, with a C that is.

If your looking for an easy professor this is not one.  He will make you work hard.  BUT he is very good at what he does.  His teaching meathods have been revised and perfected to make you learn.  Coming out of a Cooperstien class may be hard...but its quality and worth it.

Where do I begin.  His midterm exams are too long (and he readily admits it) and are overly difficult.  The midterms are more proof rather than computational, which makes things frustrating.  He uses his own textbook for the course, which can be frustrating at times.  His lectures can also be very confusing.

This is a problem solving course, so be ready to be frustrated if you aren't good at word problems. Take this class with a group of friends so you can work together on problems. He doesn't teach much, so I would have preferred more guidance.

the exams are easy if you remember that you cannot rely on your professor to teach you everything! and you definitely can't rely on bruce because he doesn't realize which concepts are most difficult. you have to actually read the textbook, then you will be set.

Too picky about how a student answers exam questions, has trick questions too. doesn't teach you how to apply theorems, just shoves 'em in your face, when you don't use them properly he spazzes out. BUT, he is trying to improve on his teaching so tell him what you think.

This class is a weeder class.  It exists so the prof can find cool smart kids to talk to.  He ignores those who he deems not so smart.  Plus he doesn't teach.  He just says, "here's some problems, figure them out." Avoid this class and guy.
A FUN math class if you can believe it. A new way to use mathematics for problem solving. Thought the teacher did a fine job with the material and the concepts.
VERY HARD!!!! STRICT MEAN!!!
